request_pathways.name: Fax to UF Health HIM Dept – ROI (352.265.1098)
Mail to UF Health HIM Dept – ROI, P.O. Box 100348, Gainesville, FL 32610-0348

forms.document_type: ROI authorization form (clinic-specific variant for UF C.A.R.D.)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients download a generic HIPAA authorization form from the medical records page, print and handwrite it, then fax or mail it to the HIM department.

red_flags: Per-page fee ($1.00/page) applied uniformly without distinguishing patient access from third-party release, potentially exceeding HIPAA cost-based fee limits for individual access requests
bright_spots: MyUFHealth patient portal offered as an electronic delivery format
16 granular record-type checkboxes with separated sensitive-information categories (behavioral health, substance use disorder, STD/HIV/AIDS, genetic testing)
'Personal Use' listed as an explicit purpose option, validating patient self-access
Identity verification fields marked 'Internal use only' to reduce patient burden
Compact single-page form design with logical section flow

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation — the medical records page (ufhealth.org/medical-records) links directly to the primary form, and web searches return relevant results; minor deduction for multiple undifferentiated form versions at different URLs that could confuse patients.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — despite being born-digital, the PDF has zero fillable fields across all four form versions, requiring patients to print and handwrite; fax submission is available but the form completion itself is entirely paper-based.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor clarity issues — logical single-page layout with clear section flow, 16 granular record-type checkboxes, and reasonably plain language; minor issues include dense corporate entity definition paragraph and visual density from fitting all content on one page.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the generic authorization framework treats patient self-access identically to third-party release, with only a 'Check here if same as patient' checkbox as accommodation; no Right of Access language, though 'Personal Use' purpose option and internal-only verification fields show some awareness.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements that may go beyond what the law requires for patient access — the $1.00/page fee disclosure does not distinguish patient access (subject to HIPAA cost-based limits) from third-party release (subject to state fee schedules); no notarization or in-person barriers, and clear revocation rights partially offset this concern.

overall.summary: UF Health Shands provides an easily findable and well-organized authorization form but is held back by a fully paper-based workflow (no fillable fields), a generic authorization framework that does not differentiate patient self-access, and per-page fee language that may exceed HIPAA limits for individual access requests.
